The UX of AI deathbots

Peeping under the hood of Microsoft Copilot but quickly slamming down the lid

As the market for generative AI matures, a shift is occurring. From the initial boasts of technologists, PR bluster and social media half-facts, a more mature discovery of practical, real world utility and use-case scenarios are emerging.

Can Generative AI help speed up learning how to code?

For example, currently, I am teaching myself Python via a Harvard course (available for free on EdX). The terms of participating in the course, for those interested in earning a certificate, include an ethics code that prohibits the use of AI in assignments. However, my learning outcomes are more flexible and experimental. Particularly, I am interested in seeing if AI can speed up the process of learning code.

So, because of trends like “vibe coding”, I have been experimenting to see how to incorporate generative AI into a coding process. Some argue that this is the inevitable future.

Might as well start early.

The design of AI chatbots

Generative AI chatbots have a kind of samey look. OpenAI and Google Gemini are pretty bland. Perplexity and Claude try to do something more interesting by using contemporary style. To my surprise, it is…
